docs.lead_paragraph: There is no medical reason that healthy women in their 50's should be prevented from having babies with donated eggs, the largest study of motherhood after menopause has found. While healthy postmenopausal women are likely to have Caesarean births and face high rates of pregnancy-induced diabetes and high blood pressure, the conditions are temporary and not reason enough to exclude them from trying to get pregnant, the researchers found in a study to be published today.

headline.main: Donor-Egg Pregnancies Called Safe After Age 50

docs.abstract: Study of outcomes for 77 postmenopausal women who took part in University of Southern California's assisted reproduction program finds there is no medical reason that healthy women in their 50's should be prevented from having babies with donated eggs; finds such women are likely to have Caesarean births and face high rates of some temporary, pregnancy-induced ailments (M)
docs.snippet: There is no medical reason that healthy women in their 50's should be prevented from having babies with donated eggs, the largest study of motherhood after menopause has found.    While healthy postmenopausal women are likely to have Caesarean births...

docs.lead_paragraph: A torrent of front-page revelations, accusations and countercharges about the royal household is challenging the monarchy's hold on the nation's regard just months after it was emphatically revalidated by the celebration of Queen Elizabeth II's 50 years on the throne. The festivities in June with millions of Britons thronged outside Buckingham Palace and lustily cheering their sovereign and her family on the balcony were a hearty emblem of the Windsors' recovery from the dark days after the death in 1997 of Diana, Princess of Wales.

headline.main: Royal Palace Is Roiled Again By New Round of Revelations

docs.abstract: British monarchy's hold on nation's regard is being challenged by torrent of front-page revelations, accusations and countercharges about royal household; new headlines involve charges that Prince Charles hushed up rape of manservant by one of his closest aides, that courtiers regularly brought male prostitutes into royal palaces and that Paul Burrell, former butler to late Princess Diana, had once taken male lover of his own on tour of queen's private apartment; it was Burrell's aborted trial on charges of plundering Diana's estate, and his subsequent decision to sell his story to tabloid Daily Mirror, that started rush to print by Britain's aggressively competitive newspapers (M)
docs.snippet: A torrent of front-page revelations, accusations and countercharges about the royal household is challenging the monarchy's hold on the nation's regard just months after it was emphatically revalidated by the celebration of Queen Elizabeth II's 50...

docs.lead_paragraph: People with severe acne will soon be permitted to buy a generic version of the drug Accutane if they follow strict rules intended to keep it from pregnant women. Health officials have worked for years to associate the name Accutane with birth defects so women with any prospect of pregnancy will know to avoid it. A generic version of the drug, which the Food and Drug Administration approved on Friday, will be sold under its chemical name, isotretinoin. The question now is whether doctors and women will connect the name to Accutane.

headline.main: Generic Version of Acne Drug To Be Sold, With Precautions

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves generic version of acne drug Accutane; for years health officials have worked to associate name Accutane with birth defects so women with any prospect of pregnancy will know to avoid it; question now is whether doctors and women will connect name of generic drug, Isotretinoin, to Accutane; generic version to be made by Genpharm, unit of Merck of Germany (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JANE PRATT, the editor of Jane magazine and a practiced interpreter of postfeminist girl culture, phoned from Paris not long ago to chat about her latest stroke of fortune. ''Here I was at the European collections making my way at the Christian Dior show,'' Ms. Pratt, 39, recalled. ''The room was so crowded I didn't know how I was going to make it to my seat. But all of a sudden the ushers and even the other editors parted to make way for me,'' she said. ''Believe me, it's never happened before.''

headline.main: Sexy Singles, Make Way for Glamour Moms

docs.abstract: Article on attention being paid to celebrities and otherwise ordinary women who are pregnant or are new mothers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Although a lot of tender care clearly went into the making of ''The Rising Place,'' this misty-eyed Southern nostalgia piece, in treading the line between sappy and sanguine, winds up mired in tear-drenched quicksand. Set mostly in the 1940's, the story is a series of flashbacks from the deathbed of gentle, wise Emily Hodge, known as Aunt Millie (Alice Drummond), whose rebellious salad days growing up in the Mississippi Delta are recounted. The catalyst for the magnolia-scented memories that flood the screen is the discovery by the dying woman's niece, Virginia Wilder (Frances Fisher), of a cache of old letters and photographs. When we first meet Emily (Laurel Holloman), she is proudly pregnant by Harry Devening (Jackson Walker), a handsome young aviator who disappears, never to return. That pregnancy is not the only thing about Emily that scandalizes Hamilton, the small town where the film is set. A stubborn loner with a precocious sense of social justice, she raises eyebrows by hanging out with Wilma Watson (Elise Neal), an ambitious, idealistic young black woman who is studying to be a schoolteacher, and Will Bacon (Mark Webber), a teenage pariah whose ostracism by his peers is never satisfactorily explained.

headline.main: A Small-Town Southerner Who Chooses Rebellion Over Being a Belle

docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie The Rising Place, directed by Tom Rice with Laurel Holloman and Elise Neal; photo (M)
